title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act is titled the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998". The Congress recognizes the need to streamline over 600 Federal financial assistance programs to address complex problems efficiently at the local level. The Congress acknowledges the need to simplify over 600 Federal financial assistance programs to address complex issues efficiently at the local level, hindering cost-effective service delivery. State, local, and tribal governments, along with nonprofit organizations, are facing intricate problems that require coordinated service delivery. Streamlining Federal financial assistance procedures will enhance public service delivery. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, "Federal agency" means any agency defined under section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code, and "Federal financial assistance" has the same meaning as defined in section 7501(a)(5) of title 31, United States Code. Federal financial assistance is defined as assistance provided to a non-Federal entity, while a local government is a political subdivision of a State. A non-Federal entity includes States, local governments, and nonprofit organizations. The term "nonprofit organization" refers to any organization operated primarily for scientific, educational, service, charitable, or similar public interest purposes. The term "nonprofit organization" refers to any corporation, trust, association, cooperative, or other organization that operates primarily for scientific, educational, service, charitable, or similar public interest purposes, is not organized primarily for profit, and uses net proceeds to maintain, improve, or expand its operations. The term "State" includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories, as well as Indian Tribal Governments. The term "tribal government" refers to an Indian tribe as defined in section 7501(a)(9) of title 31, United States Code. The term "uniform administrative rule" is a government-wide rule for generally applicable requirements. The term "tribal government" refers to an Indian tribe as defined in section 7501(a)(9) of title 31, United States Code. The term "uniform administrative rule" is a government-wide rule for generally applicable requirements established to achieve national policy objectives across multiple Federal financial assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Federal agencies must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment. The plan should streamline procedures for financial assistance programs, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, and designate a lead agency official. The Act requires federal agencies to demonstrate appropriate use of a common application system, designate a lead agency official, allow electronic application and reporting for funds, ensure timely and high-quality information from recipients for federal reporting requirements. The Act mandates federal agencies to establish annual goals and objectives to measure performance in achieving the Act's purposes, which can be part of the agency's annual planning responsibilities under the Government Performance and Results Act. The Act requires federal agencies to set annual goals and objectives to measure performance, which can be part of their annual planning responsibilities under the Government Performance and Results Act. If agencies cannot comply, the Director must report the reasons for noncompliance to the relevant committees. The Director must report to relevant committees if agencies are unable to comply with setting annual goals and objectives. The Director may extend the period for plan development for noncompliant agencies for up to 12 months. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register and receive public comments on it. The Director may extend the period for plan development and implementation for noncompliant agencies for up to 12 months. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register, receive public comments, and hold public forums on the plan. Each Federal agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register and hold public forums for public comment. The lead official must consult with non-Federal entities during plan development and implementation. Each Federal agency must submit their plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance. The report may be included in general management reports required by law. The Director is responsible for specific duties. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall establish a common system for applying, managing, and reporting on funding from multiple Federal financial assistance programs administered by different agencies, with uniform administrative rules. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall establish a common system for applying, managing, and reporting on funding from multiple Federal financial assistance programs administered by different agencies, with uniform administrative rules. This includes processes for non-Federal entities to streamline and simplify administrative procedures and reporting requirements for Federal financial assistance programs. The Director will establish an interagency process to streamline and simplify Federal financial assistance administrative procedures and improve coordination of information sharing among agencies. The Director may designate a lead agency and working groups to improve reporting requirements, interagency coordination, and information quality for Federal financial assistance programs. The Director may designate a lead agency and working groups to assist in improving the timeliness, completeness, and quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. Agencies are required to submit information and reports to the Director for review upon request. The Director may designate a lead agency and working groups to assist in improving information quality from recipients of Federal financial assistance. Agencies must submit information and reports for review upon request, and the Director may exempt agencies from certain requirements if deemed necessary. The Director may exempt Federal agencies or financial assistance programs from the Act if they have few programs. Exempted agencies will be listed on OMB's website. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act. The evaluation, to be submitted within 4 years, will assess the Act's effectiveness and provide recommendations for further implementation. The evaluation of the Act will assess its effectiveness in meeting its purposes, agency performance, and coordination among various entities. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION.

The Act allows Federal agencies to gather necessary information for reviewing the financial integrity of activities receiving Federal financial assistance.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW.

There is no provision for judicial review of compliance with the Act, and no rights enforceable through administrative or judicial action.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET.

This Act will be effective upon enactment and will expire five years later. SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS. This Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.
